summary.seg: Cambridge, Trinity College MS R.14.51 is a miscellany of practical and instructive works of the kind typically found in circulation in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries. It comprises two codicological units, similar in decoration and style of handwriting, that have been bound together. Such compilations may have been used by healers, leech doctors or, sometimes, by individuals or families in domestic contexts. Though this manuscript shows signs of having been professionally produced, the combination of treatises and the organisational principles, as well as the overwhelming preference for English over Latin (though we find a few lines of French at f. 25v) suggests that it was used perhaps by a community leech doctor and not a barber-surgeon. As Elaine Miller ((1978), p. xxxiii) has argued, the fifteenth-century practitioner who owned and used the book was 'extremely pragmatic, possibly eclectic, and most probably fairly unsophisticated'. The presence of some ballads (e.g. f. 95r, copied by a later hand) and texts like The Boke of Marchalsi, a prose work on equine medicine, might indicate a wider context for the volume, one that extends the remit beyond the realm of health and healing.

Health and healing, however, are common preoccupations in manuscripts of this kind. Just like today, people struggled with all sorts of ailments and healthcare issues. In Trinity MS R.14.51, we witness a clear interest in the preservation and clear presentation of charms and cures for a range of ailments, among them toothache, the 'falling evil' (what we might call epilepsy today), to help women in childbirth, eye complaints, and to staunch the flow of blood. Many of the cures are short and not too complex, suggesting that the leech doctor may have not been overly-proficient. At f. 28r, for example, we find an economical instruction to mend 'broken bones in mannys heede' that advises the reader to treat it topically with ground agrimony, or else to drink an infusion of betony to help set the bones and heal the wound. Agrimony as an ingredient in a cure for the same complaint recurs at f. 32v, where it is mixed with honey and used to bathe the wound. The instructions at f. 28r are immediately followed by a charm to catch a thief, discussed below. Based on the context and accessibility of the cures, it is likely that these would have been used by self-taught medical man. These receipts are neatly – probably professionally – copied, making good use of visual strategies to break up the text, enabling easier consultation. Throughout there are of decorative initials, blue and red paraphs marking breaks in the text or indicating another version of a charms or recipe, and headings in rubric, features that taken together render the manuscript easily consultable. Additionally, some of the remedies, particularly those found at the beginning of the manuscript (from ff. 1r–5r) are in verse, arguably in order to help readers or users commit some of them to memory.

Many of the medical receipts are generically close to charms and prayers, again a typical situation in the later medieval period. For instance, the instructions in this manuscript to help a woman through a difficult childbirth, known as the Maria peperit Christum charm, are based on a Latin prose prayer about the Blessed Virgin Mary's delivery of Jesus. The charm is to be written on parchment and bound about the stomach of the labouring woman. It is found here at f. 16r. Yet other charms in the volume involve writing out certain words or formulae and having a patient - or, in this case, a suspect - ingest the ground up parchment. Here, at f. 28r, we find a charm to catch a thief that asks the reader to '[T]ake and write þese lettres folowynge and ʒeve hit to eete to þo þat þou haste suspicion to and ʒif he be culpable hit schall not passe hys throte.' The required letters are copied out in red to distinguish them from the other instructions. Interestingly, in this manuscript the instructions to write out remedies or methods to discover something are grouped together, suggesting a high level of organisation across the second part of the volume. Alongside the charm to catch a thief we also find written charm, here called a 'fayre medecyne' for 'the foule evil' that asks the reader to write a series of names, including those of the three wise men, on parchment, and to hang it around the neck of the afflicted person. The manuscript also contains two short tracts on medical diagnosis by urine colour (ff. 18r-18v and 32r-32v).

Many of the cures in the manuscript rely on the use of herbs, and therefore it is not surprising to discover, beginning at f. 34v, a lengthy verse herbal, the Tretys of Diverse Herbis. Written in rhyming couplets, the text is based on the Latin Macer Floridius, and is extant in some sixteen other manuscripts. It opens with an explication of the properties and uses of betony, the very herb that is called for the medicine to heal head wounds, mentioned above: 'To telle of betoygne I haue gret mynde / And of other erbes as I fynde.' The herbal is the central treatise in the manuscript, offering cures using not just betony but herbs such as motherwort, celandine and burnet, as well as commonly grown garden flowers like roses and lilies. Here again we find a firm association between cures and charms, as well as an interest not just in cures but wellbeing more generally and other life matters. One of the instructions for celandine requires the reader to gather the herb early on Lammas day (August 1st), to hold it high and to say 'pater noster and Auees þree'. For this person, '[N]o prison schall hym holde no dore. / He schall ouercome all hys enemys.'

Relatedly, there is a strong interest in prognostication and astronomy in the volume, and these aspects may have been useful for our leech doctor as he worked out the optimal times for medical treatment, the reign of the planets, and the phases of the moon, and also (un)lucky days and those best for favourable outcomes. Among these tracts is an abridged version of the well-known and widely-coped Wise Book of Philosophy and Astronomy (ff. 77v-86r), an accessible guide to the planets and their influence and reign, as well as the signs of the zodiac. There is a cluster of similar texts at the beginning of the volume. At f. 16r is a tract on favourable times of the month in which to administer medicines based on astronomical conditions, a text known as 'A general teachynge to ʒeue medecyns'. And grouped together at ff. 18v–22r are two treatises on the moon, one concerned with bloodletting and the other with destiny, demonstrating further the complementary nature of the material in this volume. The presence of ownership inscriptions (including the names John Fertho, Jacob Hawkins of Worcester, and George Atkinson) as well as the drawing of a horse-mill with the inscription 'Bussell' at the opening of the manuscript (potentially referring to a family of that name near Chester (see Mooney (1995)), indicates that the volume maybe have held value in the context of the gentry or landed family as well as for healers and leech doctors.

Dr Carrie Griffin
Ollamh Comhlach, Béarla / Associate Professor, English
Scoil an Bhéarla, na Gaeilge agus na Cumarsáide / School of English, Irish and Communication, Ollscoil Luimnigh / University of Limerick

Elaine M. Miller, 'In Hoote Somere': A Fifteenth-Century Medical Manuscript (unpublished PhD dissertation, Princeton University, 1978)
Linne R. Mooney, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist 11: Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge (Oxford: D.S. Brewer, 1995), pp. 49–53

msContents.textLang: Middle English, Latin, and Middle French

msItem.title: Gentilesse
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: i verso [T]he first for the fadre of gentylnes / W\h/o[...]lk kleymyht gentyl for to be
msItem.explicit: i verso And [...] to R[evei]se savely dar y deme / A[...] were he myhter croune or deyodeme

msItem.title: Lak of Stedfastnesse
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.incipit: ii recto Wylum the wordule was stedefaste and stable That mannys word was oblygacyun
msItem.explicit: ii recto Drede god do law loue trouþe and Ryhtwysnis / And wedde ayeyn thy folke to stedefastnes

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Six medical recipes, including a list of ingredients for making a dry stew for treating sciatica.

msItem.title: Table of contents to the medical recipes
msItem.note: Written in English by a late 16th- or early-17th-century hand onto two inserted paper leaves.

msItem.title: A book of medical recipes in English verse and prose
msItem.textLang: Middle English with some Middle French
msItem.incipit: 1r In hoote somere þese erbes þou take / And styllyd watere of hem þou make
msItem.explicit: 18r þerof make plastres gode and fyne / And warme lay it to pyntel thyne

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: Method to drive flies out of a house with vervain and holy water

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]
Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]
Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: On the gathering, storing, and preparation of herbs for salves
msItem.incipit: 10v Burnet wodebynde weybrede rybeworte mouser and puliset ys but oon erbe
msItem.explicit: 11v but ȝif he were hurte in a gut or in hert or in brawne þis drynke wolle saue hys lyf and þis ys thynge þat ys prouede

msItem.title: Fortunate Days for Bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 11v fforto knowe þe days of blode lattynge
msItem.incipit: 11v Who so wole late hym blode þe secunde day of Mache he schalle haue no tesyk þat yere
msItem.explicit: 12r Who so lettith hym blode þe first monday of Juyll he ys in perell of deth

msItem.title: On the Perilous Days
msItem.rubric: 13r The maister hathe nombre xxxij perelous days in þe yere Who so falle in sykeness þo days he schall not couere . Who so ys þan borne schall not long lyue Who so bygynnys ony grete jorney to make schall neuere come a[g]ene . Who so weddith any wyf they schall hastely be departede ore elles leue euere in angere and in tene . thus telles the doctoure and þese are þe days
msItem.incipit: 13r In Januere are vij days þe first þe ijde þe iijde þe vte þe xte þe xvth and þe xvijth
msItem.explicit: 13r In Decemb[e]r are iij days þe vjth þe viijth þe viijth thise bene þe perelous days

msItem.title: Charm for inducing a safe childbirth

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: Astrological instructions for using medicines ('A general rewle for to geue medycyne')
msItem.incipit: 16r Who so takith medecyns laxatyfs whan þe mone ys in þe planete of Jubiter hys werke schall enfeble . ffor þe wyse man seith who so ys a leche and knoweth nouȝte of Astronomye he ys like a blynde man þat goth with a staf and sekith þe wey.
msItem.explicit: 16v ffor Jubiter conforteth þe nature and encreceth þe force and þe strenght and þe strenght offendeth þe effecte of þe medecyne

msItem.title: On the astrological signs of the Zodiac and parts of the human body
msItem.rubric: 16v Tholomeus a general rewle to þe maister of Surgerie to knowe þe signes þat seruen to membres and thus are þe signes
msItem.incipit: 16v Aires Taurus Gemina Cancer Leo Virgo Libra Scorpio Sagittarius Aquarius Pisces Capricornes Aries hathe of a man þe hede and the face
msItem.explicit: 16v And þerfore moste a leche or a barboure knowe alle þe signes and alle þe membres And what tyme he schalle [g]eue hys medecyns or hys drynkes or hys oynementes or eny oþere þinge to doo to eny membre

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English with two Middle French recipes at the end

msItem.title: Urine White and Brown with the Six-Token List from the Letter of Ipocras (Token 5 only)
msItem.rubric: 18r Here folowe howe þe doctour techith þe howe þou schalte knowe vryne
msItem.incipit: 18r-18v Vryne white at morne and Broune aftere mete that ys signe of good hele
msItem.explicit: 18v Vryne of man or of woman þat hathe þe ffeuere and þat haue a blak gaderynge on þat on halfe of the vrenal þat ys signe of dethe thyse ben þe signes of vryne

msItem.title: Lunary for bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 19r Here begynnyth þe waxynge of þe mone and declareth dyuerse tymes to be laten blode whiche bene gode
msItem.incipit: 19r In the firste begynnynge of þe mone hit ys profitable to eche a man to be laten blode in the splene
msItem.explicit: 20r Also þe xxxti of þe mone in no tyme it yst not gode

msItem.title: Days of the Moon (Collective lunary)
msItem.rubric: 20r Here begynnyth also of þe mone and declareth what tyme a body ys bore what hy schall befall
msItem.incipit: 20r In the firste begynnynge of þe mone all þinge ys profyteable to a man in þat tyme And ȝif a knaue Childe be þan borne sche schall be benygne Chast bothe faire and likynge to men
msItem.explicit: 22r In the xxx of þe mone yf a knaue childe be borne he schall be blessyd trewe stronge anad benygne . And ȝif a maide childe be þan borne sche schalbe swete and y blessyd

msItem.title: On lucky and unlucky days for bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 22r I rede euery wyse man take gode heede of þe lithere days in þe yere
msItem.incipit: 22r And a man be laten blode those þre days schal dye within iiij days or vij days with oute doute
msItem.explicit: 22v-23r Also who so bledeþ Non Junij schall suffre deþe or fallynge euell or elles a grete sorowe

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: The collection includes an instruction for blode lattynge on f. 26r [see below].

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]
Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: Charm for a pregnant woman for safe childbirth

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: On the virtues of bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 26r In mesure clense þe bladder of a man or of a woman and tempreth þe brayne hit mendithe þe herynge and destroyeth þe teres hit clansethe þe mawe hit desyeth þe meete hit clereth þe voice hit gadreth sclepe hit dryueth away angwys and norysshith gode blode and destroyth wicked blode it lenghisth the lyf of man or of woman

msItem.title: Charm to deliver a pregnant woman of a dead child

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: Dietary
msItem.author: Galen
msItem.rubric: 26v Now here techith Maister Galian leche of mete and drynke and also of tyme of blode letynge
msItem.incipit: 26r In þe monethe of Jenuere white wyne ys gode to drynke fastynge And be not lat blode
msItem.explicit: 28r And iij days þere are of parell þe xvth þe xvjth and þe xvijth who so vsith þis ilke lyf he schall dredeles haue gode hele

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English with Latin and Middle French used in charms

msItem.title: Charm to identify a thief with magical characters written on food

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]
Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: Charm to heal wounds with a lead plate (attributed to 'Ypocras')

listBibl.bibl: Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]
Miller (1978) [editions of the charms on ff. 1r-45r]

msItem.title: Token list of Urines of Death ['Urine Troubly with Clouds']
msItem.rubric: 32r To knowe þe euell in vren of man or of woman
msItem.incipit: 32r Yf the vryne of a syke man be trouble And ȝif hit haue cloudes abouen fletande thhe deth of hym it betokeneth
msItem.explicit: 32v vryne ȝelow ȝif it white drop it signifiethe tribulacion and angwyssh certeynly

msItem.title: On a sign of death
msItem.rubric: 32v The signe of rede thorne ventosynge and blode latyng of veyne
msItem.incipit: 32v The blode þat ys alle reede and drye withoute watere and in the mydwarde hathe a white drope þat ys verrey signe of deþe withoute fayle

msItem.title: Poem on bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 33r Modus qui docet ad minuendum hominis sanguinem
msItem.incipit: 33r For to kenne þe veynes to late blode / To þe þat lates many gode men blode
msItem.explicit: 33v Whan þe heede hathe any nede / ffor all þe body in myddes þe arme

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe is imperfect due to a missing leaf before f. 34.

msItem.title: A tretys of diverse herbis (especially Betony)
msItem.incipit: 34v To telle of betoygne I haue gret mynde / And of other erbes as I fynde
msItem.explicit: 47r He castith wele to þe eyne sight / Thys medecyne ys prouede I the plight
msItem.note: The text is imperfect due to the loss of a leaf between f. 33 and f. 34; and another leaf between f. 35 and f. 36.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Seven medical recipes added by three hands (the first one added a recipe to the lower margin of f. 47r; the second one six to the empty page of f. 47v; and the third a seventh recipe on f. 47v)), both dating from the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Magical rituals and charm to heal farcy in a horse
msItem.note: The same charm occurs in Cambridge, University Library, Dd.4.44.

msItem.title: Charm to heal affected veins in a horse
Book of Marshalcy [Marchalsi]
msItem.incipit: 48r and the breste and after that lere hem to bere her haltres and make the reyne of þe haltres longe so þat þey may treden þeron
msItem.explicit: 77v And the hors schall haue hele and amende of hys sikenes like as he seith þat hath proued the Charme
msItem.note: This treatise on veterinary medicine in the form of question and answer contains charms and instruction for how to make a bath for a horse (ff. 70r-70v).

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 56v This indentur maide the eliven daye of ffebreuarie in the sex raine of the yere of Our Souering [sic] ladie quene Elizabeth by the grace of God
msItem.note: Full transcription; copied in or after 1563/4, perhaps also added lines from a draft indenture to the upper margin of f. 73r.

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 73rThis Indenture made the
msItem.note: Full transcription; perhaps added by the same 16th-century hand that added lines from a draft indenture to the outer margin of f. 56v.

msItem.title: The Wise Book of Astronomy and Philosophy
msItem.rubric: 77v Here bygynnyth the Wyse boke of Phylosophy and Astronomy contynued and made of þe wyseste Phylesophre and astronomyer þat euere was sith the worlde was begonne þat ys to sey of þe londe of Grece ffor yn that londe an ynglys man full wyse and wele vnderstondynge of Phylosophy and Astronomye stodyed and compyled thys boke oute of grewe into englysshe tongue graceously
msItem.incipit: 77v ffirst þis boke tellith how many hevenes þer beth afterwarde he pronouncith and declarith of þe course and of þe gouernaille of þe planetes afterward of þe signes and of þe sterres of þe firmament
msItem.explicit: 94v And after he schall wex wyche and gladliche schall forswere hym and yf he be take prisonere in bataylle
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly due to a missing leave/leaves or a quire.

msItem.title: Balade fet de la Reygne Katerene Russell
msItem.textLang: Middle English poem with a Middle French title
msItem.incipit: 95r Slombryng Ryhgt thoutefull ful of vnkyndenes / That now haþe Reyne and dominacyun
msItem.explicit: 95r Whos hey nobeles in euery cuntrey / Adew the curt Right gentyl large and fre
msItem.note: Balade fet de la Reygne Katerene Russell

supportDesc.support: Parchment (ff. i-iii, 1-95); and Paper (ff. iv-v) folded in folio featuring the watermark of a Jug with a crown and the initials PI at the centre of the page.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos of all leaves; the numbers 45 and 46 are missing from the sequence but not representing missing leaves in the manuscript.

Folios [a]-[b] and [c]-[d] are early modern paper flyleaves. Folios i-iii and 95 are original parchment flyleaves with 15th- and 16th-century additions. folios iv-v are inserted paper leaves with an index to the manuscript that was added in the late 16th or early 17th century.

foliation.p: Written in brown ink on the upper left-hand corners of the rectos of all leaves; this sequence misses the numbers 47, 96, and 97. These missing numbers coincide with missing leaves in the collation and breaks in the text, suggesting that three leaves have gone missing in the early modern period.

collation.p: This collation deviates from that by M.R. James (1901) in that it refers to ff. i-iii as Quire 1 instead of Quire a (NB: as a result, all quire numbers in the collation are one ahead of the collation numbers used by James and noted in the manuscript). Based on missing sections from a treatise on herbs, it also identifies Quire 6 (James's Quire 5) as a quaternion that is missing two leaves rather than a sexternion.

p.formula: 14-1 (3rd missing) [Two inserted paper leaves] 28-1 (1st missing) 3-58 68-2 (3rd and 6th missing) 78 88-1 (1st missing) 9-138 [A single leaf]

signatures.p: Leaf signatures (Roman numerals) occasionally visible (e.g. Quire 8) on the lower right-hand corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in brown ink in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires

condition.p: The manuscript's first three parchment leaves (ff. i-iii) are cockled and have creases in their lower right-hand corners. The recto of the first folio features dark (ink?) stains.
The offset of a round (? metal) object with concentric circles is visible on ff. 82v-83r.

p.seg: Folios i verso and ii recto have been ruled in ink, frame only for a single column, possibly by the same hand that ruled ff. 1-194. 28 lines to the page, written below top line (the other folios do not feature ruling and their texts seem to have been added without layout plan).
Ruled in ink, frame only. Single columns. 28-30 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The texts on ff. i verso, ii recto, and 95r were added by a scribe who produced a 15th-century cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.
The texts on ff. ii verso-iii recto were copied by a scribe who produced a 15th-century cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.
A medical recipe added to the lower margin of f. 47r was added by a scribe who produced a late 15th- or early 16th-century cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.
The first five medical recipes added to f. 47v was added by a scribe who produced a 15th-century cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.
The final (sixth) medical recipe added to f. 47v was added by a scribe who produced a 15th-century cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.
Folios 1r-47r, 48r-94v were copied by a scribe in a neat cursive script resembling Anglicana formata (but with Secretary features).

decoNote.p: A large (full-page) drawing in dark ink, featuring a circular horsemill inside a roundel, probably representing a rebus, with below the name Bussell written in large decorated letters flanked by a standing human figure in prayer.
Large (2 lines) blue initials in frameworks of red penwork decoration with pen-flourishing in red ink extending into the outer margins
Line-fillers in blue and red ink.
Crossed in red ink drawn in the texts of charms throughout the manuscript.
Paraphs alternating between blue and red ink.

note.p: Quire numbers (Araberic numerals) have been added by a modern hand in pencil on the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires.
Notes about missing lines and leaves have been added by pencil in the lower and upper margins of pages (see ff. 33v, 34v-35r).

binding.p: Half leather binding over pasteboards; brown speckled leather on the sides; the spine with five raised bands and three paper labels with the printed shelfmark: R, 14, 51.

provenance.p: Clare, John John Clare : his 15th- or 16th-century signature inscribed in the left margin of f. i verso: by me John Clare.
Hees, Simon Simon Hees : his name inscribed by a (?) late 15th or early 16th-century hand in the lower margin of f. ii recto: Simoneum Hees is brickle [...].

Bussell [? Russell], J. [? John] J. [? John] Bussell [? Russell] : their surname Bussell (? or Russell) written in large calligraphic script that is typical of the 15th century below a drawing of a horse-mill in a roundel on f. iv verso. The horse shaft resembles the letter J.

James Hawkins (fl. 1679-1680) Hawkins, James, fl. 1679-1680 of Worcester: donated the manuscript to George Atkinson in 1679/80 according to an inscription in the upper margin of f. 1r: 'Sum e libris Geo : Atkinson ex dono Jacobi Hawkins Ciuitatis Wygorniensis dat. febru: 13o 1679/80'.

George Atkinson Atkinson, George: received the manuscript from James Hawkins in 1679/80 according to an inscription in the upper margin of f. 1rSum e libris Geo : Atkinson ex dono Jacobi Hawkins Ciuitatis Wygorniensis dat. febru: 13o 1679/80.

history.acquisition: Acquired by Trinity College Library at an unknown point in time between 1680 and 1900: the College's shelfmark R.14.51 is printed on paper labels pasted onto the spine; written in pencil on the inside of the front cover; and in ink in the upper right-hand corner of f. 1r (together with an old shelfmark that has been crossed out: B.8[?].33. The college's early modern armoarial bookstamp (Coll: Trin: Cant:) printed on a paper pastedown on the lower half of f. iii recto; it's ownership stamp in dark ink on f. 94v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, 2 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1901); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: Supplementary Parallel Text Edition of Chaucer's Minor Poems, Containing Most of Those That Could Not Be Got into the Parallel-text Edition
The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue
